text.p: These are the leading stories in the Namibian press on Monday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Parliament in South Africa voted on Friday to write off a 1.242 billion rand debt owed by Namibia since independence.

- Enviroment and Tourism Minister Gert Hanekom is optimistic that Namibia will be authorised to start a limited trade in elephant products at the forthcoming 1997 meeting of the Convention on International Trade in Engangered Species (CITES) in Harare. Hanekom said that CITES was impressed with Namibia's management of its wildlife resources.

- Only the Namibian side of the joint technical committee dealing with the controversial Epupa Hydro Power project wants to continue with a second site study on the Kunene river. A consultant's report has recommended that future investigations should concentrate on the smaller site E only, but according to a NamPower spokesman, the Namibians want the much larger Site B incorporated in the final study.

- Over 100 employees of building company International Construction Ltd have demanded information about their pensions contributions that were paid into the Insurance group Sanlam's "Namibia Building Workers Pension Fund".
